title.rendered: A Guide to Business Setup in Dubai, UAE in 2023

content.rendered:
Are you looking for a new business setup in Dubai, UAE? If so, you’re in luck! Dubai is a great place to do business, with a strategic location, favorable business environment, and low tax rates.

But setting up a business in Dubai can be a complex process. That’s where we come in. We’ll walk you through the entire process, from choosing the right free zone to obtaining your trade license.

We’ll also provide you with all the information you need to know about the different legal structures available, the required documents, and the fees involved

So what are you waiting for? Let’s get started!

Why Set Up a Business in Dubai in 2023?

Dubai is a great place to set up a business in 2023. Discussed below are some important reasons for this:

  • Strategic location: Dubai is located at the crossroads of the world, with easy access to Europe, Africa, and Asia. This makes it a great place to export your products or services to a global market.
  • Business-friendly environment: Dubai has a favorable environment for business setup and operations, with minimal taxes, simple regulations, and a strong legal system. These factors make setting up a business hassle-free in Dubai.
  • Low tax rates: Dubai has one of the lowest corporate tax rates in the world, at just 9%. Taking advantage of this can lead to substantial tax savings for your business.
  • Access to skilled labor: Dubai has a large pool of skilled labor, thanks to its large expatriate population. This means that you can easily find the talent you need to grow your business.
  • Government support: The Dubai government is supportive of businesses, and offers a number of incentives to attract foreign investment. This includes free zones, tax breaks, and grants.

Types of Business Zones in Dubai, UAE

Free Zones

Free zones are special economic zones that offer a variety of tax and regulatory benefits to businesses. They are located outside of the mainland of Dubai and are governed by their own rules and regulations. This makes them a popular choice for businesses that want to avoid the high taxes and regulations of the mainland.

Some of the benefits of setting up a business in a free zone include:

  • Low or zero taxes: Free zones typically offer very low or even zero taxes on corporate profits, income, and capital gains.
  • Simplified regulations: The regulations governing businesses in free zones are typically much simpler than those on the mainland. This can make it easier and quicker to set up and operate a business in a free zone.
  • Access to foreign markets: Free zones offer easy access to foreign markets, as they are typically located near major ports and airports.

Mainland

The mainland is the area of Dubai that is not governed by a free zone. It is subject to the same tax and regulatory rules as the rest of the UAE. This makes it a good choice for businesses that want to operate in the UAE market and that want to be able to trade with businesses on the mainland.

Some of the benefits of setting up a business on the mainland include:

  • Access to the UAE market: Businesses on the mainland have full access to the UAE market, which is a large and growing market.
  • Ability to trade with mainland businesses: Businesses on the mainland can easily trade with businesses on the mainland, as they are subject to the same rules and regulations.
  • Strong legal system: The UAE has a strong legal system, which provides businesses with a high degree of protection.

Offshore

Offshore zones are similar to free zones, but they are specifically designed for businesses that trade internationally. They typically offer even lower taxes and regulations than free zones, and they are often located in remote areas. This makes them a good choice for businesses that want to minimize their tax liability and that want to operate in a discreet environment.

Some of the benefits of setting up a business in an offshore zone include:

  • Very low taxes: Offshore zones typically offer very low or even zero taxes on corporate profits, income, and capital gains.
  • Simplified regulations: The regulations governing businesses in offshore zones are typically much simpler than those on the mainland or in free zones. This can make it easier and quicker to set up and operate a business in an offshore zone.
  • Secrecy: Offshore zones typically offer a high degree of secrecy, which can be important for businesses that want to keep their financial dealings private.

The best business zone for your business will depend on your specific needs and requirements. If you are looking for a low-tax environment with simplified regulations, then a free zone may be a good choice for you. If you want to operate in the UAE market and trade with businesses on the mainland, then the mainland may be a better choice. And if you want to minimize your tax liability and operate in a discreet environment, then an offshore zone may be the best choice for you.

Types of Business Licenses in Dubai, UAE

The following are some of the most common types of trade licenses in Dubai:

Commercial License

The most frequently seen business license in Dubai is the commercial license. It is required for businesses that engage in trading activities, such as selling goods or services. The issuance of Dubai commercial licenses is overseen by the Department of Economic Development (DED).

Professional License

This type of license is required for businesses that offer professional services, such as accounting, law, or engineering. Professional licenses in Dubai are issued by relevant professional bodies, such as the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) or the Dubai Chamber of Commerce and Industry (DCCI).

Industrial License

This type of license is required for businesses that engage in manufacturing activities. Industrial licenses in Dubai are issued by the DED.

Tourism License

This type of license is required for businesses that offer tourism-related services, such as hotels, restaurants, or tour operators. Tourism licenses are issued by the Department of Tourism and Commerce Marketing (DTCM).

Free Zone License

This type of license is required for businesses that operate in a free zone. Free zones are special economic zones that offer a variety of tax and regulatory benefits to businesses. You can obtain a freezone license in Dubai from the free zone authority.

Offshore License

This type of license is required for businesses that trade internationally. Offshore licenses are issued by the offshore authority.

The type of business license you need will depend on the nature of your business activities. If you are not sure which type of license you need, you can contact the DED or the relevant professional body like A&A Associate for more information.

In addition to the above, there are also a number of other types of business licenses that may be required, depending on the specific activities of your business. For example, if you are a restaurant, you may also need a food handling license. And if you are a construction company, you may also need a building permit.

It is important to check with the relevant authorities to make sure that you have all of the necessary licenses before you start your business. Not following this requirement may lead to financial penalties or even the shutdown of your company.

Check out the differences between a DED license and Freezone License to know more about your business requirements.

Process of Business Setup in Dubai, UAE

Before jumping into company registration in Dubai, know the thorough process involved below:

Choose a business structure

The first step is to choose the legal structure for your business. There are a number of different structures available, such as a sole proprietorship, a limited liability company (LLC), or a free zone company. The structure you choose will depend on a number of factors, like your business size, the number of owners, and the level of liability you are comfortable with.

Choose a business zone

You also need to choose a business zone in Dubai. There are three main business zones: the mainland, the free zones, and the offshore zones. The business zone you choose will depend on your specific needs and requirements.

Get the required licenses and approvals

Once you have chosen a business structure and a business zone, you need to get the required licenses and approvals. The specific licenses and permits you need will depend on the nature of your business and the business zone you are operating in.

Register your business

Next, registering your business with the relevant authorities will be required. The registration process will vary depending on the business structure you have chosen and the business zone you are operating in.

Open a bank account

The next important step is opening a corporate bank account in Dubai for your new business setup. This will allow you to receive payments and make payments.

Obtain a visa and residence permit

If you are not a UAE national, you will need to obtain a visa and residence permit for yourself and any employees you hire.

Set up your business premises

You need to set up your business premises. This may involve renting or buying an office or warehouse.

Start trading

Once you have completed all of the above steps, you can start trading.

Documents Required for Business Setup in Dubai

  • Passport: You need to provide a copy of your passport, both the front and back pages.
  • Visa: If you are not a UAE national, you need to provide a copy of your visa.
  • Proof of residence: You need to provide a copy of your proof of residence, such as a utility bill or a bank statement.
  • Memorandum of Association (MOA) and Articles of Association (AOA): You need to provide the MOA and AOA of your company. These documents will set out the rules and regulations of your company.
  • Power of attorney: If you are not going to be present in Dubai to set up your business, you need to provide a power of attorney to someone who will set up your business on your behalf.
  • Shareholders’ details: You need to provide details of the shareholders of your company, such as their names, addresses, and passport numbers.
  • Directors’ details: You need to provide details of the directors of your company, such as their names, addresses, and passport numbers.
  • Trade license: You need to obtain a trade license from the Department of Economic Development (DED) before you can start trading.

The specific documents required may vary depending on the business structure you have chosen and the business zone you are operating in. For example, if you are setting up a free zone company, you will need to provide additional documents, such as a lease agreement for your office space.

To know more about the legalities of business setup in Dubai, contact one of the best business setup companies in Dubai, A&A Associate for the latest information on the markets.
